comment:
The present game seems to have been the earliest occasion
on which this opening appeared in master play.

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e5 3. dxe5 d4 4. Nf3 Nc6 5. a3
comment:
Not bad, but White could play Nc1-d2 at once, followed by the fianchetto of
the KB with a definitely superior game. 5...

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e5 3. dxe5 d4 4. Nf3 Nc6 5. a3 Bg4 6. h3 Bxf3 7. gxf3 Nxe5 8. f4 Nc6 9. Bg2 Qd7 10. b4 a6 11. Bb2 Rd8 12. Nd2 Nge7 13. Nb3 Nf5 14. Qd3
1. d4 d5 2. c4 e5 3. dxe5 d4 4. Nf3 Nc6 5. a3 Bg4 6. h3 Bxf3 7. gxf3 Nxe5 8. f4 Nc6 9. Bg2 Qd7 10. b4 a6 11. Bb2 Rd8 12. Nd2 Nge7 13. Nb3 Nf5 14. Qd3 Be7 15. Be4 Nd6
comment:
The weakness of Black's QP has prevented him from
obtaining a natural development. The result is that his position is already
lost.

comment:
and Black resigns. An unorthodox conclusion to an unorthodox
game. From "Lasker's Greatest Chess Games 1889-1914" Dover Publications - New
York 1965
